turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: We'll hear argument now in Garcetti v. Ceballos.
Ms. Lee.

turn.speaker: cindy_s_lee
turn.label: Ms. Cindy S. Lee
turn.text: Chief Justice Roberts, and may it please the Court:

The issue presented is whether the first amendment requires protection for all public employee speech that touches on a matter of public concern without any consideration of whether the speech was expressed as a citizen.
The ninth circuit's approach affords no consideration for the role of the speaker as a citizen or an employee at the time of the speech.
This approach, however, plants a seed of a constitutional claim in virtually every speech that public employees express while carrying out their regular job duties.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Well, that's... I mean, I can see--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Do you think that the court tried to apply the Pickering test?

turn.speaker: cindy_s_lee
turn.label: Ms. Cindy S. Lee
turn.text: The ninth circuit clearly did not apply the Pickering test when they were doing the initial analysis, a threshold analysis, of whether or not the speech at issue was constitutionally protected.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Do you think that the Pickering test, properly applied, would have reached a different result in this case?

turn.speaker: cindy_s_lee
turn.label: Ms. Cindy S. Lee
turn.text: Not necessarily, not the way the ninth--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: It could have--

turn.speaker: cindy_s_lee
turn.label: Ms. Cindy S. Lee
turn.text: --circuit viewed it.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: --certainly.

turn.speaker: cindy_s_lee
turn.label: Ms. Cindy S. Lee
turn.text: Well, in the ninth circuit's view, the capacity of an employee at the time of the speech is of some factor.
It's a determinative factor.
But, in its view, it was a factor that should be weighed against finding no constitutional protection.
In its view--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Do you think that the proper application of Pickering would yield a different result in this case?

turn.speaker: cindy_s_lee
turn.label: Ms. Cindy S. Lee
turn.text: --Our view is that--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Could it?

turn.speaker: cindy_s_lee
turn.label: Ms. Cindy S. Lee
turn.text: --if the application of the Pickering is re articulated such that when job required speech is at issue, like in this case, the employer should invariably win or have a... an easier time of prevailing.
But, in this case, the ninth circuit didn't see it that way.

The ninth circuit took the view that the capacity of an employee at the time of the speech is a factor, but it would be difficult for an employer to justify employment decisions made when the employee is speaking as required by the duties of employment.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: --Counsel, you made the point that if we go the ninth circuit way, every time an employee gets Dutch there's a potential first amendment issue.
Why hasn't that been a problem since 1988 in the ninth circuit?
I think 1988 was the year of the circuit's Roth decision.
So, we haven't seen a deluge, and doesn't that rather discount your argument?

turn.speaker: cindy_s_lee
turn.label: Ms. Cindy S. Lee
turn.text: Well, our view is that if we accept the ninth circuit's approach, then speech by public employees expressed while carrying out their assigned job duties would virtually... invariably be--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: cindy_s_lee
turn.label: Ms. Cindy S. Lee
turn.text: --a matter--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: I realize that, but that... as I understand it, that has been true since the ninth circuit's Roth decision in 1988.
And apparently we have not seen a deluge of these claims, or we would have had citations to the cases.
So, doesn't that rather discount the concern that you express?

turn.speaker: cindy_s_lee
turn.label: Ms. Cindy S. Lee
turn.text: --Not necessarily.

The ninth circuit and the other circuits that have made, primarily, content the determinative factor in finding presumptive first amendment protection have, in some regards, considered the capacity of an employee as whether or not the speech should be protected under the first amendment, but they've done so in the context of whether or not it is a matter of public concern.
So, the ninth circuit is alone in having addressed squarely whether or not job required speech should not be afforded presumptive first amendment protection.
The other--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: But didn't... maybe I'm wrong on my assumption, but didn't the ninth circuit take that position, back in 1988?

turn.speaker: cindy_s_lee
turn.label: Ms. Cindy S. Lee
turn.text: --That's correct.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Okay.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: What do you do if a public university professor, who... is fired for the content of his lectures?
Certainly, in the course of his employment, that's what he's paid to do.
That has no first amendment protection?

turn.speaker: cindy_s_lee
turn.label: Ms. Cindy S. Lee
turn.text: Well, it would be our view that if the assigned job duties of that university professor was to speak on a particular topic or content, and they were getting paid for doing that, that that is a job required % speech and that it should not be entitled, presumptively, % to first amendment protection.
Now, that is a far cry from--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: "Should not be entitled, presumptively, to first amendment protection. "
what does that mean?
That there might be first amendment protection, in light of the particular context--

turn.speaker: cindy_s_lee
turn.label: Ms. Cindy S. Lee
turn.text: --Our--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: --of the speech?

turn.speaker: cindy_s_lee
turn.label: Ms. Cindy S. Lee
turn.text: --Well, according to the ninth circuit's view, anything... anytime a public employee speaks, and that speech relates to a matter of public concern, that is presumptively entitled to first amendment protection, such that the burden is on the employer to justify the decisions for the employment actions taken.
Our view is that the employer should not have that burden until the first threshold is made, that the speech is expressed as a citizen on a matter of public concern.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: I suppose that, in the situation the Chief Justice mentioned, the professor would still be able to contend that the university fired him because it disagreed with the political content of his speech or because of the university's politics.
He could still make that claim, couldn't he?

turn.speaker: cindy_s_lee
turn.label: Ms. Cindy S. Lee
turn.text: Our approach would not prohibit that--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: But the--

turn.speaker: cindy_s_lee
turn.label: Ms. Cindy S. Lee
turn.text: --kind of--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --burden would be on him, as it would be in most cases--

turn.speaker: cindy_s_lee
turn.label: Ms. Cindy S. Lee
turn.text: --That's correct, Justice Scalia.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --to show that that was true.

turn.speaker: cindy_s_lee
turn.label: Ms. Cindy S. Lee
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Whereas, the ninth circuit would put it on the... put the burden on the university to show that it wasn't true.

turn.speaker: cindy_s_lee
turn.label: Ms. Cindy S. Lee
turn.text: That's correct.
The ninth--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: I would have thought you might have argued that it's speech paid for by the Government, that's what they pay him for, it's their speech; and so, there's no first amendment issue at all.

turn.speaker: cindy_s_lee
turn.label: Ms. Cindy S. Lee
turn.text: --In essence, the principle of our approach is supported by those Government subsidizer cases, like the Rust v. Sullivan.
Our--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: But in Rust v. Sullivan, the Government was buying a commodity.
It was the Government's program, and it was employing people, funding people to implement that program.
Here is a person whose job includes being candid, serving justice, serving truth.
If that's part of his job responsibilities, that's quite different from speaking the speech that the Government wants spoken.

turn.speaker: cindy_s_lee
turn.label: Ms. Cindy S. Lee
turn.text: --Well, in this case, we think that the job duties are aligned with those subsidizer cases.
We have a deputy district attorney whose job duty was to assess the merits of the prosecution's case, which he did.
That includes assessing the credibility of a witness.
Because his conclusions in this case were that the prosecution's witness was not very credible does not make that task extraordinary.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: I guess if your job is to speak truth, and you speak falsehood, that's a good reason to fire you, which is what happened here.

turn.speaker: cindy_s_lee
turn.label: Ms. Cindy S. Lee
turn.text: That could be a--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: But you don't--

turn.speaker: cindy_s_lee
turn.label: Ms. Cindy S. Lee
turn.text: --legitimate reason.
Or--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --contend that, do you?

turn.speaker: cindy_s_lee
turn.label: Ms. Cindy S. Lee
turn.text: --or the employer doesn't--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Do you contend--

turn.speaker: cindy_s_lee
turn.label: Ms. Cindy S. Lee
turn.text: --necessarily have to--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: --that his statement was false?
Do you contend the speech was false?

turn.speaker: cindy_s_lee
turn.label: Ms. Cindy S. Lee
turn.text: --Our position is that the speech was inaccurate and that--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Well, but how do we know that?
We're at summary judgment.

turn.speaker: cindy_s_lee
turn.label: Ms. Cindy S. Lee
turn.text: --Well, we have the... the deputy district attorney's disposition memorandum assessed that... in his view, that the prosecution was going to lose on the pending motion to dismiss, in... on the grounds of that the search warrant was going to be... was going to be found invalid.
That was the essence of the deputy district attorney's assessment.
And in his memorandum, as part of his prosecutorial duties, he evaluated that.
He told his supervisor,
"Look, you know, I'm looking at the credibility of the officer. "
"I conducted an investigation. "
"I don't think we're going to win on this case. "
The supervisor initially thought,
"Okay, you have a point. "
but ultimately decided,
"You know what? "
"I'm not as sure as you are. "
"We have a motion to traverse on calendar, where we have a judge who's going to be assessing that, so let's see what happens. "
That judge found that the search warrant was valid.
And so, in essence, we have a public employee who is challenging employment decisions made by his supervisors--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: No, I realize that, but where do you... how do you infer, from that, that the individual, the employee, was not telling the truth?

turn.speaker: cindy_s_lee
turn.label: Ms. Cindy S. Lee
turn.text: --That--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: If--

turn.speaker: cindy_s_lee
turn.label: Ms. Cindy S. Lee
turn.text: --It is not our--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: --if I--

turn.speaker: cindy_s_lee
turn.label: Ms. Cindy S. Lee
turn.text: --position--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: --if my ethical record amounted to a lie every time I made a... an inaccurate prediction about what a court was going to do when I was a young lawyer, I would have had a very short career.
[Laughter]
And that seems to me as much as you can infer from what this individual did.

turn.speaker: cindy_s_lee
turn.label: Ms. Cindy S. Lee
turn.text: --Justice Souter, it is not our position, and we have never taken the stance, that the deputy district attorney in this case was reckless in regards of his speech--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Oh.
Okay.

turn.speaker: cindy_s_lee
turn.label: Ms. Cindy S. Lee
turn.text: --or his evaluation.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: So, we don't--

turn.speaker: cindy_s_lee
turn.label: Ms. Cindy S. Lee
turn.text: Our view is that--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: --we don't know why it didn't pan out the way he said it was going to, and we don't know that he was... that he was lying.

turn.speaker: cindy_s_lee
turn.label: Ms. Cindy S. Lee
turn.text: --Correct.
What--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Okay.

turn.speaker: cindy_s_lee
turn.label: Ms. Cindy S. Lee
turn.text: --we do know is that the... it is our view that the supervisor... while the supervisor contended that he did not react to this speech adversely, that he could have.
We have here speech that was required by the job.

The employee here... if we take the ninth circuit's approach, we would be providing public employees a constitutional right to perform their assigned job required duties in a way that is to the dissatisfaction of the public employer.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Yeah, but you don't have to establish that he was lying; just that his prediction... his job, was to predict, and he made a... an erroneous... a false prediction.
Don't have to show that he intended to do that.

turn.speaker: cindy_s_lee
turn.label: Ms. Cindy S. Lee
turn.text: That's correct, Justice Scalia.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Yes, but the disposition by the... I mean, his grievance by the hearing examiner was that there was no retaliation.
He assumed that the speech was proper and there was no inefficiency or misconduct on the part of the speaker.

turn.speaker: cindy_s_lee
turn.label: Ms. Cindy S. Lee
turn.text: Well, the internal grievance procedure resulted in the finding that the supervisors did not retaliate against the deputy district attorney for the... for his job required duties.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: And, in my understanding, that was the only defense that was made for the charge, that, "We didn't retaliate".
There was no claim that the speech was improper in any way.
Am I wrong on that?

turn.speaker: cindy_s_lee
turn.label: Ms. Cindy S. Lee
turn.text: That's correct--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Yeah.

turn.speaker: cindy_s_lee
turn.label: Ms. Cindy S. Lee
turn.text: --Justice Stevens.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: So, we assume, for purposes of our case, that what he said was totally accurate and did not, itself, provide the basis for saying he was incompetent or something of that... like that.

turn.speaker: cindy_s_lee
turn.label: Ms. Cindy S. Lee
turn.text: Well, we assume, for purposes of the summary judgment motion, that he was within his prosecutorial duties in making those assessments.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Can I ask you one--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Excuse me, I'm not sure I understood the answer to the first question, John.
Was he not fired because he had made an improper assessment?

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: --No.

turn.speaker: cindy_s_lee
turn.label: Ms. Cindy S. Lee
turn.text: No, our position has never been that the supervisors took any retaliatory action as a result of his speech.
He was not fired.
What the--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: cindy_s_lee
turn.label: Ms. Cindy S. Lee
turn.text: --deputy district attorney--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: cindy_s_lee
turn.label: Ms. Cindy S. Lee
turn.text: --challenges here is various employment decisions by his supervisor, claiming that they were in retaliation for him having prepared and communicated a disposition memorandum that was within the course and scope of his employment duties.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: And your defense is that the--

turn.speaker: cindy_s_lee
turn.label: Ms. Cindy S. Lee
turn.text: Our--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --actions were not taken with any reference to this... to this at all.

turn.speaker: cindy_s_lee
turn.label: Ms. Cindy S. Lee
turn.text: --our position has been that the employer could certainly have reacted, or responded, to the speech or the way he conducted his job, or performed his job, but they didn't, in this case.
There were... there were legitimate business reasons for the employment--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: But that's surely a--

turn.speaker: cindy_s_lee
turn.label: Ms. Cindy S. Lee
turn.text: --decisions made.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --surely a factual inquiry, which will be disputed.

If you want to win on summary judgment, it seems to me you have to establish that, assuming he was fired because of this speech, that would be... or not promoted because of his speech... that would be perfectly okay.

turn.speaker: cindy_s_lee
turn.label: Ms. Cindy S. Lee
turn.text: That's correct--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: That's where--

turn.speaker: cindy_s_lee
turn.label: Ms. Cindy S. Lee
turn.text: --Justice Scalia.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --we are.

turn.speaker: cindy_s_lee
turn.label: Ms. Cindy S. Lee
turn.text: That's--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: We assume--

turn.speaker: cindy_s_lee
turn.label: Ms. Cindy S. Lee
turn.text: --that's correct.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --that that was the reason for the later actions.

turn.speaker: cindy_s_lee
turn.label: Ms. Cindy S. Lee
turn.text: And the problem with the ninth circuit's approach is that every time there is job performance at issue that's required by the public employee, it essentially puts the question before a jury or a Federal court to assess the motives--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: But what is your position?

turn.speaker: cindy_s_lee
turn.label: Ms. Cindy S. Lee
turn.text: --to assess the reasonableness of the decisions made.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Ms. Lee, is your position that job required speech... an assistant district attorney's obligation is to give his best opinion... that job required speech is outside the first amendment protection?
You say the ninth circuit went too far, in one way.
But are you saying that as long as it's related to his job, it's simply not protected by the first amendment?
Is that your position?

turn.speaker: cindy_s_lee
turn.label: Ms. Cindy S. Lee
turn.text: Our view is that job required speech is not of a character for which principles of first amendment should protect.

In Pickering, the public school teacher sought to be treated as a member of the general public when he sent his letter to the newspaper criticizing the allocation of financial resources by the school board.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Yes, I understand--

turn.speaker: cindy_s_lee
turn.label: Ms. Cindy S. Lee
turn.text: Nothing like that arises--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: --I understand that, but I was confused by your answer to Justice O'Connor, because the question was, Would this come out a different way under Pickering?
And I take it your answer is, this doesn't come in the door, because he's not speaking as a citizen.

turn.speaker: cindy_s_lee
turn.label: Ms. Cindy S. Lee
turn.text: --Under the current... my... under my current understanding of the Pickering balancing... which is... shifts the burden to the employer to justify the employment decisions made... that we don't... I don't necessarily believe that the Pickering would clearly weigh in favor of the employer in this case, even though the speech was so connected to the duties of employment--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: I'm confused.
You think that this... there was an aspect of it that was citizen speech?
Why--

turn.speaker: cindy_s_lee
turn.label: Ms. Cindy S. Lee
turn.text: --No.

turn.speaker: cindy_s_lee
turn.label: Ms. Cindy S. Lee
turn.text: We contend that it should... in situations where the speech at issue is job required, and that employee is getting paid for engaging in that kind of duty, that the balance should weigh in favor of the employer.
And I believe the respondent--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: --Well, what do you mean--

turn.speaker: cindy_s_lee
turn.label: Ms. Cindy S. Lee
turn.text: --concedes as much.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: --by
"the balance, weigh in favor? "
Because, a moment ago, I thought you answered me,
"This kind of speech simply is not shielded by the-- "

turn.speaker: cindy_s_lee
turn.label: Ms. Cindy S. Lee
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: --"# first amendment".

turn.speaker: cindy_s_lee
turn.label: Ms. Cindy S. Lee
turn.text: Our... the... our view is that job required speech should not be protected under the first amendment, so there is no need to go into the balancing, there is no need to go into the weighing of the interests of the employer versus the interest of the employee.

The balancing has been required in the... in the line of cases that the court has held... the language that the court has used in this first amendment public employment context is, when you do the balancing, you weigh the interests of the State, as an employer, versus the interests of the employee, as a citizen, when engaging in this speech.
Our view is that the balancing should only be required when the--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: You would give--

turn.speaker: cindy_s_lee
turn.label: Ms. Cindy S. Lee
turn.text: --public employee--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: --greater protection to a public speech than to a comment from... on the job from... to one's superior.

Can you give me an example of a statement that would provide... be entitled to complete first amendment protection if made in a speech, but could justify a discharge if made face to face with your employer?

turn.speaker: cindy_s_lee
turn.label: Ms. Cindy S. Lee
turn.text: --I'm sorry, could you repeat that?

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Could you give me an example of a statement that would be protected in a public speech, but, if made privately to your superior, could provide the basis for a discharge?

turn.speaker: cindy_s_lee
turn.label: Ms. Cindy S. Lee
turn.text: I believe the Court's referring to facts similar to Givhan, where there you had speech made privately to a supervisor, and--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Which was--

turn.speaker: cindy_s_lee
turn.label: Ms. Cindy S. Lee
turn.text: --this Court--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: --protected.

turn.speaker: cindy_s_lee
turn.label: Ms. Cindy S. Lee
turn.text: --this Court has found that it was protected under the first amendment.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: cindy_s_lee
turn.label: Ms. Cindy S. Lee
turn.text: However, the Court did not need to address the role of the speaker in that case, because there you had an English teacher who was criticizing the racial--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: You're not--

turn.speaker: cindy_s_lee
turn.label: Ms. Cindy S. Lee
turn.text: --policies--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: --responding to my question.
My question is, Can you give me an example of a statement that would be entitled to protection if made in a public speech, but could be a basis for discharge if made face to face?

turn.speaker: cindy_s_lee
turn.label: Ms. Cindy S. Lee
turn.text: --It could be in this case, where the prosecutor, who is assigned, or authorized, to speak on behalf of the DA's office in a pending criminal action, made comments to the press about the nature of the case, but, rather... and, in this particular scenario, goes too far, goes beyond what the DA's office allowed him to speak on.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: No, I'm--

turn.speaker: cindy_s_lee
turn.label: Ms. Cindy S. Lee
turn.text: He could--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: --asking you if--

turn.speaker: cindy_s_lee
turn.label: Ms. Cindy S. Lee
turn.text: --certainly be discharged for that.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: --what he says privately could the basis for a discharge.
Surely, he couldn't be discharged for what you just described.

turn.speaker: cindy_s_lee
turn.label: Ms. Cindy S. Lee
turn.text: The... under our approach, the issue is not whether it's privately or publicly.
If the job requires him to speak in a... within the internal channels, then that speech... he's doing his job, he's getting paid for it, and he should not be entitled to first amendment protection.
Unless there are any other questions--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Is that--

turn.speaker: cindy_s_lee
turn.label: Ms. Cindy S. Lee
turn.text: --I'd like to--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: --is that true in this case?
I realize they didn't get to it on summary judgment, but is that true in this case with respect to a Brady disclosure?

turn.speaker: cindy_s_lee
turn.label: Ms. Cindy S. Lee
turn.text: --Brady disclosures are the obligations of the district attorney's office.

So, in this case, when the deputy district attorney believed that it should be disclosed, his supervisor had an absolute right to, say, on behalf of the DA's office, challenge that decision to disclose.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: What if... what if the lawyer simply believes that he has an ethical obligation to make the disclosure, and he makes it, and he is then subject to retaliation?
No first amendment claim on his part?

turn.speaker: cindy_s_lee
turn.label: Ms. Cindy S. Lee
turn.text: Those ethical obligations would build... would arise from his capacity as a prosecutor.
Prosecutors are employees.
Governmental employees have a general standard of ethical conduct.
That doesn't mean that they are getting paid for the same assigned job duties.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Well, does that mean... what's your answer to my question?
If he makes the Brady disclosure because he believes that is an ethical obligation, and he is then subject to retaliation, does he have a first amendment claim, or not?

turn.speaker: cindy_s_lee
turn.label: Ms. Cindy S. Lee
turn.text: It's our view that he does not.
I'd like to reserve the remainder of--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: Thank you--

turn.speaker: cindy_s_lee
turn.label: Ms. Cindy S. Lee
turn.text: --my time for rebuttal.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: --Ms. Lee.
Mr. Himmelfarb.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: What's your answer to that last question, Mr. Himmelfarb?

turn.speaker: dan_himmelfarb
turn.label: Mr. Dan Himmelfarb
turn.text: A Brady obligation is an obligation of a prosecutor in his capacity as a prosecutor; and a Brady disclosure, like a recommendation to a superior that there should be a Brady disclosure, constitutes the exercise of the prosecutorial function by a prosecutor.
It is employee speech, and that speech, if it engenders an employment action, should not be sufficient for the employee to get past the first step of the Pickering balancing.
If there is--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: So, no free speech protection under Pickering.

turn.speaker: dan_himmelfarb
turn.label: Mr. Dan Himmelfarb
turn.text: --That's exactly right, Justice O'Connor.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: And how about this case?
Could it not be resolved under a proper handling of Pickering?

turn.speaker: dan_himmelfarb
turn.label: Mr. Dan Himmelfarb
turn.text: Well, we think a proper handling of Pickering is that respondents should not get past step one of the balancing, because the speech is expressed in his capacity as an employee.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Now, what about retaliation claims that the employee may have?
What about whistleblower type claims by an employer?
Are they... are they separate from the first amendment concerns?

turn.speaker: dan_himmelfarb
turn.label: Mr. Dan Himmelfarb
turn.text: We don't think they are, Justice O'Connor, if the whistle blowing is required by the employee's speech.

If an investigator in an inspector general's office, whose job it is to investigate and report government misconduct, reports misconduct, and an action is taken as a result... an employment action is taken against them as a result... he is demoted or transferred, because it's the view of his superior that he didn't perform his job properly in speaking on that issue... that should not enable the investigator to get past the first step.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: What if the reason... what if the reason for the... for firing him is that he's a Democrat and it's a Republican Administration, and the speech is used as the pretext?

turn.speaker: dan_himmelfarb
turn.label: Mr. Dan Himmelfarb
turn.text: Justice Scalia, I think that case would be covered by this Court's patronage cases, which would absolutely prohibit that sort of employment action.

But in a case where it's not party affiliation that motivates the employment action, if the speech is expressed in carrying out the employee's duties, he may have a civil service remedy... indeed, that's precisely what the civil service laws were designed to deal with, a situation where the employee is just doing his job, an action is taken again him, and there's a dispute as to whether he was doing his job properly, about whether he was insubordinate, or simply about whether he was--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Suppose that we have an instance where it is job related.
He is not speaking as a private citizen, and it's also a public concern.

Now, in such an instance, could we say that, at least if the matter of public concern rise to the level where it's related to an independent constitutional protection... say, founded in the due process clause... under those circumstances, the employer cannot unreasonably... though we give him an area of discretion, he cannot unreasonably retaliate.

turn.speaker: dan_himmelfarb
turn.label: Mr. Dan Himmelfarb
turn.text: --I don't think so, Justice--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Why not?

turn.speaker: dan_himmelfarb
turn.label: Mr. Dan Himmelfarb
turn.text: --Breyer.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Why not?
And here is an independent obligation.

turn.speaker: dan_himmelfarb
turn.label: Mr. Dan Himmelfarb
turn.text: To--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: It's very unusual--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: --but it's there.

turn.speaker: dan_himmelfarb
turn.label: Mr. Dan Himmelfarb
turn.text: --To use the example of this case, if respondent advised his supervisor that, in his professional judgment, a Brady disclosure should be made, and if the supervisor disagreed with him, and if reasonable minds could differ as to whether the disclosure should be made, and he made it, nonetheless, he would be insubordinate.
And we don't think that that is the--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: You'd only lose... the Government would lose, only where you can conclude that they could... "they", the Government... could not... could not reasonably conclude that he'd been insubordinate.

turn.speaker: dan_himmelfarb
turn.label: Mr. Dan Himmelfarb
turn.text: --Justice Breyer--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: So, we covered the case of the Democrat, Republican, et cetera.
In other words, we'd give him... should we give him total discretion?
Can't we limit that discretion of the supervisor?

turn.speaker: dan_himmelfarb
turn.label: Mr. Dan Himmelfarb
turn.text: --If it's... if it's a situation where reasonable minds cannot differ, and the superior directs him not to make the disclosure, in clear contravention of the due process clause as interpreted in Brady, that is a situation--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: But, Mr. Himmelfarb, in that case he could also be fired if he made the statement in a speech, could he not?

turn.speaker: dan_himmelfarb
turn.label: Mr. Dan Himmelfarb
turn.text: --If he made the statement in a public speech--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: dan_himmelfarb
turn.label: Mr. Dan Himmelfarb
turn.text: --or in a letter to the editor of a newspaper, we think that speech would be presumptively protected by the first amendment.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: But could he not be fired if the scenario you just described as--

turn.speaker: dan_himmelfarb
turn.label: Mr. Dan Himmelfarb
turn.text: Maybe he could, Justice Stevens, but that would be subject to balancing, and it would be the employer's duty to justify the firing, based on workplace disruption.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: --It seems to me odd that the employee has greater protection if he goes outside the regular channels and makes a speech than if he does... he goes right to his superior and says,
"I think this is what's wrong and should be remedied. "

turn.speaker: dan_himmelfarb
turn.label: Mr. Dan Himmelfarb
turn.text: Well, it's not that odd, Justice Stevens, because if you have an obligation to report misconduct... take, again, the example of the investigator in the inspector general's office... you will ordinarily be better off by reporting it through the ordinary channels.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: dan_himmelfarb
turn.label: Mr. Dan Himmelfarb
turn.text: Because, ordinarily, you have--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: You may have no constitutional protection.
But if you go ahead and make a speech, you do.

turn.speaker: dan_himmelfarb
turn.label: Mr. Dan Himmelfarb
turn.text: --Well, you have presumptive first amendment protection.

If you work in the inspector general's office, and there is a prohibition on disclosing pending investigations, and you hold a press conference, there is a very good chance you're going to lose at step two of Pickering, which is why it's in your interest to disclose it through appropriate channels, because--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: But it's going to be clear that that's violating your job, and it has an adverse impact on your job related duties, because you're going public, instead of going through the channels.

turn.speaker: dan_himmelfarb
turn.label: Mr. Dan Himmelfarb
turn.text: --Well, that's right.
If you have an... if it's a part of your job, you have an incentive to do it, just like any other job requirement.
And it's ordinarily not the case that public employees are punished for doing their jobs.
They're more often punished for not doing their jobs.
So, in that situation, the employee is going to likely be better off by making the disclosure through appropriate channels.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: But he has less constitutional protection.

turn.speaker: dan_himmelfarb
turn.label: Mr. Dan Himmelfarb
turn.text: That's true, Justice Stevens, but civil... it's our view that civil service laws are the mechanism for dealing with a situation where you're doing your job and there's a dispute as to whether you're doing it properly or not.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: How comfortable are you that this line you're trying to draw is one that's going to be workable in practice?
I mean, suppose the employee writes a memo, and the boss comes and says,
"If you don't promise me you're not going to talk about this publicly, you're fired. "
And he says,
"Well, I'm not going to promise that. "
And so, he's fired.
Now, is that internal, or is that external?

turn.speaker: dan_himmelfarb
turn.label: Mr. Dan Himmelfarb
turn.text: If the... if the memo is required by his job, it's--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: dan_himmelfarb
turn.label: Mr. Dan Himmelfarb
turn.text: --a recommendation about what policy the agency--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: That's--

turn.speaker: dan_himmelfarb
turn.label: Mr. Dan Himmelfarb
turn.text: --should take--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: --required by his job.
But
"promise that he's not going to talk about it. "
is not required by his job.

And this case, kind of, raises the question, because the only reason it's squarely presented on the memo is because the court didn't reach the Brady disclosure or the talk to the bar association that were related to the memo.

turn.speaker: dan_himmelfarb
turn.label: Mr. Dan Himmelfarb
turn.text: --That's right.
In answer to your question of how difficult it's going to be to draw the line, I think in most cases it won't be difficult to draw the line.
I don't think it was difficult in this case.
I'm not aware of any cases that applied principle we advocate where it has been.
There may be some cases where it will be difficult to draw the line, but--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: I suppose you have the rule which distinguishes between employment related and outside speech, under the hypothetical... difficult hypothetical posed by the Chief Justice, it would be an... the promise would be an unconstitutional condition, or something like that.

turn.speaker: dan_himmelfarb
turn.label: Mr. Dan Himmelfarb
turn.text: --That may--

turn.speaker: dan_himmelfarb
turn.label: Mr. Dan Himmelfarb
turn.text: --that may... that may be, Justice Kennedy.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: --I suppose--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: And I suppose that what constitutes a matter of public interest is not the clearest line in the world either, is it?

turn.speaker: dan_himmelfarb
turn.label: Mr. Dan Himmelfarb
turn.text: That's absolutely right, Justice Scalia.

This Court has already decided that it's important to draw a line at step one in distinguishing between speech on a matter of public concern and speech on a matter of private concern, even though it will often be hard to draw that line.
And the reason that line has to be drawn is that the alternative is, in effect, to constitutionalize the law of public employment.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Do you... let me ask you this... do you propose drawing the line... or at least drawing a line in some circumstances this way: That, at step one, if it can be concluded that a private communication between the employer and the employee would have constituted the discharge of the employee's assigned work... so that it would have been within the scope of his employment, and, therefore, not subject to Pickering balancing, if he had made the statement to the employer... that, therefore, the statement cannot be regarded as a statement of public interest, even if he had disclosed it publicly, or if he took a further step and went to the bar association and whatnot?

turn.speaker: dan_himmelfarb
turn.label: Mr. Dan Himmelfarb
turn.text: Justice Souter, we see these as two separate requirements to get past step one.
The speech has to be on a matter of public concern, but it also has to be speech in the speaker's capacity as a citizen.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: But if it is within... I'm sorry, but if it... if it is within the speaker's assigned duties as an employee, does that preclude a conclusion, later on, that he was speaking as a citizen, even if he goes public with it?

turn.speaker: dan_himmelfarb
turn.label: Mr. Dan Himmelfarb
turn.text: I don't think it does, Justice Souter.
If--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: So, we do have, then, the problem that Justice Stevens has raised.

turn.speaker: dan_himmelfarb
turn.label: Mr. Dan Himmelfarb
turn.text: --That's right.
I don't... I don't see it as much of a problem, for the reasons I tried to give in responding to Justice Stevens.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: What about the hearing at which this office had testified?
I thought that part of the complaint was,
"When I spoke at the hearing, I was speaking in a public forum, and they fired me for it. "

turn.speaker: dan_himmelfarb
turn.label: Mr. Dan Himmelfarb
turn.text: May I answer the question?

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: dan_himmelfarb
turn.label: Mr. Dan Himmelfarb
turn.text: My understanding is that that's not part of the complaint, Justice Ginsburg.
And my understanding also is that, in the district court, respondent took the position that his testimony at the hearing was in his capacity as an employee.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. Himmelfarb.
Ms. Robin Vergeer.

turn.speaker: bonnie_i_robin_vergeer
turn.label: Ms. Bonnie I. Robin-Vergeer
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court:

Ever since Pickering, it has been the law that the first amendment protects public employees from being fired or punished for expressing views on matters of public importance where, as here, there is no harm or disruption to their employers.
Petitioners in... the United States asked this Court to scrap that.
It is not just the ninth circuit.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Well, it--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Well, I'm not sure that that was clear from the decisions of this Court.
Certainly, that wasn't what was involved in Pickering.
That was outside speech.

turn.speaker: bonnie_i_robin_vergeer
turn.label: Ms. Bonnie I. Robin-Vergeer
turn.text: That's correct.
But it's been the--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: And the same... and the same with Connick.
So, I'm... if you're saying that this is what the circuits have understood, fine, but that's not this... that's why we took this case.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --And I think all the cases did say
"expressing views as a citizen on a matter of public concern. "
Wasn't that qualifier always used?

turn.speaker: bonnie_i_robin_vergeer
turn.label: Ms. Bonnie I. Robin-Vergeer
turn.text: --The qualifier has always been used in conjunction with the phase "on matters of public concern".

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: So, what does it mean?
What is... what is your explanation for that qualifier, "expressing views as a citizen"?
Why do we--

turn.speaker: bonnie_i_robin_vergeer
turn.label: Ms. Bonnie I. Robin-Vergeer
turn.text: It--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --continually say that?

turn.speaker: bonnie_i_robin_vergeer
turn.label: Ms. Bonnie I. Robin-Vergeer
turn.text: --it was used exclusively to explain, and especially to look at the context in which the phrase first appears, in Pickering, that public employees, like all citizens, have an interest--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Well, let's assume that--

turn.speaker: bonnie_i_robin_vergeer
turn.label: Ms. Bonnie I. Robin-Vergeer
turn.text: --on matters--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: --I think that that's an open question under Pickering, and that this case presents it.
Do you... do you concede... and maybe you don't... that there is any category of first amendment speech, as a matter of public concern, which an employee cannot direct to the employer?
Are there... are there some matters as to which the employer can protect its own interests and stifle the employee's speech?

turn.speaker: bonnie_i_robin_vergeer
turn.label: Ms. Bonnie I. Robin-Vergeer
turn.text: --Speaking on a matter of public concern only gets the employee presumptive first amendment protection.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: So, there's always Pickering balance.

turn.speaker: bonnie_i_robin_vergeer
turn.label: Ms. Bonnie I. Robin-Vergeer
turn.text: There would be a Pickering balance, yes.
And the Pickering balancing test is quite deferential to the employer.
The Court observed, in the Pickering case, that it's proper to look... that a court should look at the proper performance of the employee's daily duties.
In Rankin, the Court talked about the questions whether the speech interferes with work, personnel relationships, or the speaker's job performance.
The bar is already quite high for the employee, coupled with causation burdens, qualified immunity, and so on.
And so, it is not the case that just because a... an employee speaks on a matter of public concern, that that employee is necessarily going to win a first amendment case.
Also--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Ms. Lee... Ms. Lee told us that the ninth circuit weighed the capacity of the plaintiff as an employee, rather than a member of the public, in favor of the employee and against the employer.
Is that how you read the ninth circuit's decision?

turn.speaker: bonnie_i_robin_vergeer
turn.label: Ms. Bonnie I. Robin-Vergeer
turn.text: --No, I think... it's not quite right.
I think the ninth circuit just looked at whether his speech was reporting Government misconduct, a type of speech that the circuit said uniformly recognized was of paramount public importance.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: But--

turn.speaker: bonnie_i_robin_vergeer
turn.label: Ms. Bonnie I. Robin-Vergeer
turn.text: And--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: --any comment that an employee makes regarding how the office is working is a matter of public concern.
I would concede that.
I mean--

turn.speaker: bonnie_i_robin_vergeer
turn.label: Ms. Bonnie I. Robin-Vergeer
turn.text: --With--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: --that has to be.

turn.speaker: bonnie_i_robin_vergeer
turn.label: Ms. Bonnie I. Robin-Vergeer
turn.text: --with respect, I don't--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: And the consequence of your view is to have the first amendment being used for courts to monitor the discussions that take place in every public agency... local, State, and Federal... in the United States.
It's... you are advocating a sweeping rule.
Now, you'll say,
"Oh, well, Pickering balance will protect it. "

turn.speaker: bonnie_i_robin_vergeer
turn.label: Ms. Bonnie I. Robin-Vergeer
turn.text: --With--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: But I still think the intrusive consequences of your... of your rule are sweeping.

turn.speaker: bonnie_i_robin_vergeer
turn.label: Ms. Bonnie I. Robin-Vergeer
turn.text: --With respect, the public concern threshold is not so easily met.
The court has said--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: I guess our law clerks would meet it every day.

turn.speaker: bonnie_i_robin_vergeer
turn.label: Ms. Bonnie I. Robin-Vergeer
turn.text: --Maybe.
Maybe not.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Yeah, maybe, maybe not.
I don't--

turn.speaker: bonnie_i_robin_vergeer
turn.label: Ms. Bonnie I. Robin-Vergeer
turn.text: But the court has--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: --anything that goes on in my chamber that isn't a matter of public concern, and I would think everything at OSHA and everything at... look, I'll... let me put my question to you, because you're going to make an argument that I don't think is too widely shared; namely, that Pickering decides this case.
If that's your argument, I'd like to ask you a question based on the assumption Pickering does not decide this case.
And it seems to me that Pickering involves a case in which it's both a matter of public concern and outside the scope of employment.

turn.speaker: bonnie_i_robin_vergeer
turn.label: Ms. Bonnie I. Robin-Vergeer
turn.text: --Right.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: And here we have a case that is a matter of public concern, but inside.

turn.speaker: bonnie_i_robin_vergeer
turn.label: Ms. Bonnie I. Robin-Vergeer
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: So, in those circumstances, I want to know how you believe the first amendment requires us to decide this case.
And as I read this case, in the record, we have one individual, your client, who looked at an affidavit.
The affidavit said that the deputy sheriffs were trying to locate where a vehicle that was chocked up came from.
They saw tire tracks.
The tire tracks went back to a fence at the end of a long driveway.
So, I looked in the record.
I couldn't find the affidavit.
So, I assume that's what it says.
And I wanted to know what the deputy sheriff said.
What they said is that your client agreed that there were tire tracks.
There were tire tracks that did not go the whole length of the driveway, but, rather, tire tracks near the house, where they got the search warrant for.
And, they added, that... the deputies... that there was rocks broken up.
All right.
So, we have two sides to this argument: the deputies, who might reasonably contend that they did nothing wrong; your client, who thinks they were lying.
And we also have a letter that your client wrote, where he said that these deputies are grossly inaccurate and clearly misleading.
Suppose his supervisor goes to him and says,
"I think that that letter is not the right tone. "
"Maybe you're right, maybe you're wrong; maybe they're in good faith, maybe they're not. "
"And so, if you don't change that tone, I'm going to discipline you. "
All right?
Now, that's my hypothetical, which seemed to me, perhaps, very much like this case.
How, in your opinion, does the first amendment handle such a matter?

turn.speaker: bonnie_i_robin_vergeer
turn.label: Ms. Bonnie I. Robin-Vergeer
turn.text: --If the supervisor told Mr. Ceballos that there was something wrong in the manner in which he conveyed his speech, and told him to revise the memo, that would have been... he would have been well within his rights to do so.

Bear in mind that there's never been an argument here that there was anything inappropriate about Mr. Ceballos's speech, that he exercised poor judgment, that there was anything disruptive about the manner in which he communicated.
The head of the office--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: But I don't under--

turn.speaker: bonnie_i_robin_vergeer
turn.label: Ms. Bonnie I. Robin-Vergeer
turn.text: --actually said--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: --I understand the ultimate answer you gave the hypothetical.
I don't understand the principle you're following.
I mean, it's a matter of--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: --you would agree this is a matter of public concern.

turn.speaker: bonnie_i_robin_vergeer
turn.label: Ms. Bonnie I. Robin-Vergeer
turn.text: --Yes.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Which is what I'm looking--

turn.speaker: bonnie_i_robin_vergeer
turn.label: Ms. Bonnie I. Robin-Vergeer
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: --for.
I'm looking for--

turn.speaker: bonnie_i_robin_vergeer
turn.label: Ms. Bonnie I. Robin-Vergeer
turn.text: It is--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: --a standard.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: But we don't have a standard.

turn.speaker: bonnie_i_robin_vergeer
turn.label: Ms. Bonnie I. Robin-Vergeer
turn.text: --The principle is that an employer... we agree with the position of the United States, that the employer has the ability to dictate how an employee carries out his duties.
In a case where the employee--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: But in Justice--

turn.speaker: bonnie_i_robin_vergeer
turn.label: Ms. Bonnie I. Robin-Vergeer
turn.text: --is insubordinate--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: --in Justice Breyer's hypothetical, if the employee filed a lawsuit claiming a violation of his first amendment rights, you would say that could not be thrown out, on summary judgment, on the ground that the speech was within the scope of his employment.

turn.speaker: bonnie_i_robin_vergeer
turn.label: Ms. Bonnie I. Robin-Vergeer
turn.text: --It would be not on that ground.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: bonnie_i_robin_vergeer
turn.label: Ms. Bonnie I. Robin-Vergeer
turn.text: The reason it would be thrown out in summary judgment would be because the employer had a different reason for taking retaliatory action--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: Well, that would--

turn.speaker: bonnie_i_robin_vergeer
turn.label: Ms. Bonnie I. Robin-Vergeer
turn.text: --against the employee.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: --be a dispute of fact, so it probably wouldn't... so it wouldn't be thrown at summary judgment at all.

turn.speaker: bonnie_i_robin_vergeer
turn.label: Ms. Bonnie I. Robin-Vergeer
turn.text: Virtually all of these cases are able to be disposed of at summary judgment.
And you have, basically, 20 years of litigation in the circuit courts to look at where--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Look--

turn.speaker: bonnie_i_robin_vergeer
turn.label: Ms. Bonnie I. Robin-Vergeer
turn.text: --the problems that are being posited haven't materialized.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: --I'm not making my question too clear.
I'm, imagine, the district judge.
I get just the facts I described to you.
Your client, who's very upset, says,
"This is the most unreasonable thing that ever happened. "
"They were trying to prevent me from communicating with the judge. "
"I'm the one who saw the sheriffs. "
"They didn't. "
The other side says,
"We think it's reasonable what we did. "
My question to you is, What standard does that judge apply under the first amendment?
What does he do?

turn.speaker: bonnie_i_robin_vergeer
turn.label: Ms. Bonnie I. Robin-Vergeer
turn.text: The judge looks first at whether the speech is on a matter of public concern.
And if it's a dispute over Government misconduct, it would meet that threshold.

Second, the court would proceed to a Pickering balance and would say the employer's actual reason for retaliating or taking action would be because of the... you know, the tone or the message or because it was a disagreement, and the supervisor's views ultimately prevail.
And so, that's how it would be--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: So, the Federal--

turn.speaker: bonnie_i_robin_vergeer
turn.label: Ms. Bonnie I. Robin-Vergeer
turn.text: --analyzed.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: --Federal courts supervise the constant dialogue that is the everyday routine practice in every governmental agency, local and Federal, in the United States.

turn.speaker: bonnie_i_robin_vergeer
turn.label: Ms. Bonnie I. Robin-Vergeer
turn.text: With respect, no.
These cases are not that hard to dispose of at summary judgment.
Most actions that employers take against the employees are not because of the employees' speech anyway, it's because of how they carry out their job functions.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: But that would be something that would have to go to trial, to prove that the... that the employee was incompetent.

turn.speaker: bonnie_i_robin_vergeer
turn.label: Ms. Bonnie I. Robin-Vergeer
turn.text: Respectfully, I don't... I don't think that most of these cases... they don't go to trial, most of them.
They're... of course, there are some trials, but that is not the way most of these cases are handled.
And, besides that, adding an extra test, another preliminary hurdle, wouldn't change the litigation burden.
Instead of it being the Connick Pickering test, it would be Connick Pickering Ceballos test.
And then the question would be, Was the person doing their job?
How do you decide that?
Is it in his job description?
Is it a matter of custom and practice?
What if he's doing extra credit work to build up goodwill with his employer, but it's something that's not--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Well, in--

turn.speaker: bonnie_i_robin_vergeer
turn.label: Ms. Bonnie I. Robin-Vergeer
turn.text: --ordinarily required?

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: --in this case, the supervisor said,
"There can't be... can't be tracks on asphalt, so you're probably right. "
Then he finds out that it's a tire rim, and of course the rim makes a... so we have to find out this at discovery... at the discovery stage of a lawsuit?

turn.speaker: bonnie_i_robin_vergeer
turn.label: Ms. Bonnie I. Robin-Vergeer
turn.text: As long as he's made an... as long as he's made allegations or spoken in good faith in their... and it isn't demonstrably false, then he would clear that initial hurdle.
And there certainly was nothing suggesting that he spoke in bad faith or was obviously false, whether or not he was correct in his assessment.
And it wasn't just an argument over a tire rim.
He accused these... the deputy sheriff here of perjury.
It was a quite serious allegation of Government misconduct that was made here, and not, sort of, a mundane dispute over--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: Why doesn't--

turn.speaker: bonnie_i_robin_vergeer
turn.label: Ms. Bonnie I. Robin-Vergeer
turn.text: --whether or not--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: --why doesn't Rust answer this question?
I mean, there, it was really... this issue was just outsourced by the Government.
They paid for the speech there, and we said that if you pay the piper, you get to call the tune.
And this is just an insourced... the same question.

turn.speaker: bonnie_i_robin_vergeer
turn.label: Ms. Bonnie I. Robin-Vergeer
turn.text: --Ceballos was not speaking on behalf of the Government when he went to his supervisor.
That was an internal communication to his supervisor reporting--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: He was writing a memo about why the case should be dismissed.
Wasn't--

turn.speaker: bonnie_i_robin_vergeer
turn.label: Ms. Bonnie I. Robin-Vergeer
turn.text: --Right.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: --that part of his job?

turn.speaker: bonnie_i_robin_vergeer
turn.label: Ms. Bonnie I. Robin-Vergeer
turn.text: It was part of his job, although I... I'd quibble with the idea that it was required by his job.
But it was part of his job.
And, in doing so, he spoke to the Government, not as the Government.

A better analogy with respect to Rust would be if the doctor in Rust... let's say it's a doctor at a public university hospital, and the doctor was told that the policy is not to engage in abortion counseling.
And he wrote a memo to the supervisor saying,
"This is a terribly policy. "
"This is inhibiting our ability to counsel my patients and for me to do my job correctly. "
That memo would not be the Government's message.
And Ceballos's memo here to his supervisor was also not the Government's message.
But I want to... I want to get--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: Well, why is that?
In the... in your hypothetical, the doctor is... it's not his job to challenge the restriction on the Government grant, but that's what he's doing, so that's not part of his job.
Here, it's part of Ceballos's job to explain why the case should be dismissed, and that's what he wrote in his memo.

turn.speaker: bonnie_i_robin_vergeer
turn.label: Ms. Bonnie I. Robin-Vergeer
turn.text: --But this is a very malleable and manipulable concept, what's part of a job.

I mean, for a doctor to talk to his supervisor about a restriction that he feels is inhibiting his ability to counsel his patients is as much part of his job as a prosecutor going to his supervisor and saying,
"There's government misconduct in this case, and we need to do something about it. "

Just like a teacher in the Givhan case, going to her principal, a conference between a teacher and her principal about whether there's racial... racially discriminatory practices in the school would be part of a teacher's job, complaining about something that affects her students.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: What do you do with your friend's response to that, that in Connick the Court characterized Givhan as involving a case of a citizen complaining about a particular practice?

turn.speaker: bonnie_i_robin_vergeer
turn.label: Ms. Bonnie I. Robin-Vergeer
turn.text: Well, I think that underscores the point, that the employee in Givhan was speaking both as an employee and as a citizen, and these roles are not mutually exclusive.
You can be both.
There's no artificial distinction that the Court has drawn here.
And where a Government employee comes forward and reports misconduct and puts himself at risk, he is doing just that, speaking in both capacities.
And--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: We just shouldn't have said "as a citizen" in all of these cases.
We were just padding our opinion with unnecessary words.

turn.speaker: bonnie_i_robin_vergeer
turn.label: Ms. Bonnie I. Robin-Vergeer
turn.text: --The court... the court always views the "as a citizen" language in conjunction with the... speaking on a matter of public concern.
And it seems to me that the court equated the two concepts.
But I want to get to why it is unwise and unjustified to draw the per se rule that petitioners are urging here.
For one, it essentially means that a public employee such as Ceballos has to go public in order to have presumptive first amendment protection.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: But then he would be violating the internal rules of the workplace.

turn.speaker: bonnie_i_robin_vergeer
turn.label: Ms. Bonnie I. Robin-Vergeer
turn.text: Correct.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Where it's giving his candid views... the search warrant... he's giving his own opinion.
But if he goes outside, he is violating a rule of the workplace.
And it would seem to me that there are certainly measures to be taken against him for that.

turn.speaker: bonnie_i_robin_vergeer
turn.label: Ms. Bonnie I. Robin-Vergeer
turn.text: Correct.
It's a trap.
They don't tell you about what happened in the second case.
If Ceballos had taken suspicions of police misconduct and gone to the Los Angeles Times, they would have fired him.
And had he brought a case challenging that termination under the first amendment, he would have lost on under the Pickering balance.
The circuit--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: Do you think he should have lost under the Pickering balance, in that case, if he went public right away?

turn.speaker: bonnie_i_robin_vergeer
turn.label: Ms. Bonnie I. Robin-Vergeer
turn.text: --Yes.

If he had evaded proper internal channels of communication, then the employer would be well within his rights to fire him for taking an action that's so disruptive in bringing... discrediting the office without even letting his own employer try to address the situation internally first.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: What if he does let the employer try first, and the employer does nothing, then he goes public?
Where does the Pickering balance come out then?

turn.speaker: bonnie_i_robin_vergeer
turn.label: Ms. Bonnie I. Robin-Vergeer
turn.text: Closer question.
I think he probably still loses, but it's a closer question.

I think, at some point, if the magnitude of this... of the problem is so large... I mean, imagine in the Ramparts scandal situation if... which has been discussed in the briefs... if a prosecutor tried to deal with that within the DA's office, and failed to get any response, and then went public with the Ramparts scandal, something of such magnitude, a court perhaps would find their way.
But in the--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: What--

turn.speaker: bonnie_i_robin_vergeer
turn.label: Ms. Bonnie I. Robin-Vergeer
turn.text: --individual--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: --what you're saying is, is that the first amendment has an office and a function within the confines of a Government agency that it doesn't have outside.
That's a curious calculus.
It seems to me that the first amendment has its most application when you talk to newspapers, when you talk outside.
That's what the first amendment's about.
The first amendment isn't about policing the workplace.

turn.speaker: bonnie_i_robin_vergeer
turn.label: Ms. Bonnie I. Robin-Vergeer
turn.text: --The court held, in both Givhan and Rankin, that private communications on matters of public concern are still protected.
And it's... and there's very good reasons for that to be.

I mean, imagine an employee at FEMA who thinks that FEMA is not ready to handle the next hurricane, that it has problems in its disaster preparedness, and so that FEMA employee goes to his supervisor and says,
"We have problems here. "
"Here are the four areas in which we're not ready to handle the next hurricane. "
He gets fired, because the supervisor doesn't want to hear that.
It's critically important that public employees who have information, who know what ails the agencies that they work for, be able to find an avenue to communicate issues of public importance.
If that FEMA employee had gone--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Is any... is any duty of an employee in a... an agency devoted to service of the public... is any of his functions not a matter of public concern?

turn.speaker: bonnie_i_robin_vergeer
turn.label: Ms. Bonnie I. Robin-Vergeer
turn.text: --Yes.
The standard isn't anything of public interest, it's something of legitimate news interest.
The court reiterated that recently in the Roe case.
The standard does... it's not a--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: It's news.
This is a press... a press kind of a test.

turn.speaker: bonnie_i_robin_vergeer
turn.label: Ms. Bonnie I. Robin-Vergeer
turn.text: --Newsworthy.
And it's the same test--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Newsworthy.

turn.speaker: bonnie_i_robin_vergeer
turn.label: Ms. Bonnie I. Robin-Vergeer
turn.text: --the court has applied in invasion of privacy contexts.
It's... although it's a broad standard, but it's also a well known and well established standard that--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: I thought that's--

turn.speaker: bonnie_i_robin_vergeer
turn.label: Ms. Bonnie I. Robin-Vergeer
turn.text: --courts are using--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: --what Connick was about, that there are things that are said in the workplace that are of no public interest.
They're personal gripes.

turn.speaker: bonnie_i_robin_vergeer
turn.label: Ms. Bonnie I. Robin-Vergeer
turn.text: --Correct.
The line the court was drawing in Connick is between the personal and the public.

The court said that, had the prosecutor in that case come forward had... to bring to light actual potential wrongdoing, a breach of public trust, the court suggested strongly that that would have been a matter of public concern, and that the court would then--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: So--

turn.speaker: bonnie_i_robin_vergeer
turn.label: Ms. Bonnie I. Robin-Vergeer
turn.text: --have proceeded to the Pickering balance.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --so if an employee... I really don't understand it... an employee comes forward with some scurrilous information about a family member of his boss, who is a public figure, and his whole families are public figures, which would be picked up by the press, that would be a matter of public concern?

turn.speaker: bonnie_i_robin_vergeer
turn.label: Ms. Bonnie I. Robin-Vergeer
turn.text: If he's talking--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Gee, I never understood that that's what the test was.
I thought this was a matter that deals with the welfare of the public, rather than... rather than the welfare of the press.

turn.speaker: bonnie_i_robin_vergeer
turn.label: Ms. Bonnie I. Robin-Vergeer
turn.text: --Two things.
One is that if the public employee is basically reporting something corrupt in the--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Well, that I understand.

turn.speaker: bonnie_i_robin_vergeer
turn.label: Ms. Bonnie I. Robin-Vergeer
turn.text: --in the workplace.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: That's the welfare of the public.

turn.speaker: bonnie_i_robin_vergeer
turn.label: Ms. Bonnie I. Robin-Vergeer
turn.text: Correct.
And--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: No, he's--

turn.speaker: bonnie_i_robin_vergeer
turn.label: Ms. Bonnie I. Robin-Vergeer
turn.text: --in Government--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --he's just saying, you know, his boss's wife, a mayor of a big city, is running around with somebody.
Okay?
And that's picked up by the press.
It's there on the gossip pages.
She's a public figure.
You say that would be covered by this.

turn.speaker: bonnie_i_robin_vergeer
turn.label: Ms. Bonnie I. Robin-Vergeer
turn.text: --The test the court enunciated in Connick is public, social, or... excuse me... political, social, or other concerns is up to the community.
If it's something that would be of legitimate news and--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Anything that would get in the press.
That's it.

turn.speaker: bonnie_i_robin_vergeer
turn.label: Ms. Bonnie I. Robin-Vergeer
turn.text: --Then potentially--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Wow.

turn.speaker: bonnie_i_robin_vergeer
turn.label: Ms. Bonnie I. Robin-Vergeer
turn.text: --But it has to be legitimate news interest.
And the court... the courts have not usually taken idle gossip to meet that test.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: We live in a world where people are leaking things all the time.
And there are thousands of things that are in the public interest every day.

But what's bothering me is, while I see the Government's rule as protecting the interests of the employer, it's very hard for me to believe that never is there an instance where the first amendment offers protection.
But the only choice you've given me is a rule that says every dispute of the public interest is going to go right into constitutional litigation.
And I don't like that either.
So, am I hopelessly--

turn.speaker: bonnie_i_robin_vergeer
turn.label: Ms. Bonnie I. Robin-Vergeer
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: --forced to choose which is the lesser of the evils, or is there some middle approach that gives discretion to the Government, but doesn't allow them to exceed that discretion in a certain category of cases?
If so, what?
And--

turn.speaker: bonnie_i_robin_vergeer
turn.label: Ms. Bonnie I. Robin-Vergeer
turn.text: Certainly--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: --how would you phrase it?

turn.speaker: bonnie_i_robin_vergeer
turn.label: Ms. Bonnie I. Robin-Vergeer
turn.text: --at a minimum, a report of Government misconduct by an employee to his supervisor, at a minimum, should be treated as meeting whatever threshold the court establishes.
And there's something that all the all circuits that have addressed this point agree, that whistleblower types of speech is of paramount public--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: So, we do this--

turn.speaker: bonnie_i_robin_vergeer
turn.label: Ms. Bonnie I. Robin-Vergeer
turn.text: --concern.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: --so we do this as a... so we do this as a matter of what is sound management principles for a Government agency?
How does that relate to the first amendment?

turn.speaker: bonnie_i_robin_vergeer
turn.label: Ms. Bonnie I. Robin-Vergeer
turn.text: Because Government misconduct goes to the very heart of Government accountability and the public's ability to hold officials accountable when there is--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: But Government misconduct... if I get a memo from a law clerk that says, "Justice So and So's jurisprudence is wacky", that goes to--
[Laughter]
--that goes to Government misconduct, under your theory, right?
And I fire them, because I think that's not appropriate to put in a memo.

turn.speaker: bonnie_i_robin_vergeer
turn.label: Ms. Bonnie I. Robin-Vergeer
turn.text: --But if--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: They have a first amendment claim, right?

turn.speaker: bonnie_i_robin_vergeer
turn.label: Ms. Bonnie I. Robin-Vergeer
turn.text: --Well, they have a first amendment interest in their speech, but they have no claim, because if the... if you fired them just because--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Nobody's wacko here.
I mean, it's plainly--
[Laughter]
--plainly false.

turn.speaker: bonnie_i_robin_vergeer
turn.label: Ms. Bonnie I. Robin-Vergeer
turn.text: --You know, it would depend why... it would depend why you fired them.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: Well, I disagree with it.
They think it's... whatever... unprincipled, wrong.
They write me a memo, and I say,
"Don't write me a memo like that. "
And they write me another one, and then I fire them.

turn.speaker: bonnie_i_robin_vergeer
turn.label: Ms. Bonnie I. Robin-Vergeer
turn.text: All right.
But if you're firing them because you think they've exercised poor judgment in the... in the way that they've communicated, then it's--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
